What's the **80/20** of any given situation? 

What's the highest leverage activity I can do, right now?

Whether you're in business, an investor, a student or an aspiring data person, this can simplify your path.

Here's my realization for data scienceð

I made some [#datavisualizations](https://www.facebook.com/hashtag/datavisualizations?__eep__=6&__cft__[0]=AZWMc5nchn6rn68UX-wM6YYcd7xlqMYMaFkgCeVJGhCkAVBwKOMapF5LuiuiiMzodv_EAblHhNH170k4mdaSMzn2LopHxaMi9TgO0vKyeclde34QVHB4ugKojDlrjbJcl7FW1P-_lpDxR_RQ8kBOVQXEQJu1eG0uFFSLlrsVfHzPWoEKGZhkkTgBLs2KCQzla-I&__tn__=*NK-R) celebrating the BBC list of 100 influential and inspiring women in 2020.

A great (and aesthetically appealing) way to organized this list is to use a sunburstR ð·

You can ask broad and specific questions once you set up the plot, questions like:

- what % of women from Asia were recognized for their leadership

- what specific form of leadership was recognized in HK?

- how many women were recognized in the US for their knowledge? in what domain?

- what kind of creativity is being recognized in Syria?

and much more. Check it out ð

data.post: Some Tuesday inspiration for ya'llð¤©

Hello GSSE fam! 

At the start of this semester, I had no idea whether there'd be another covid19 outbreak or not. Fortunately that hasn't been one and we're almost at the end of the semester ð. It can be a stressful time so continue to ð·  and look after yourself!

Anyways, I wanted to share a quick post I've written - Statistics from the ground up - I know through my interactions with you that math ââââï¸ may not be your favorite subject, but please do try to at least *tolerate* it (esp. statistics)!

Here's a quick post on statistics from the ground up using #python: https://dev.to/paulapivat/statistics-from-scratch-with-python-18fa

Follow along if you're interested in data-related stuff: #datascience #dataanalysis #PythonForBeginners #pythonprogramming

Also some data stuff:

At the start of any #dataanalysis project, time is spent up front acquiring and cleaning data. #datavisualization is essential to getting a feel for your data.

It's especially important to *not* trust summary statistics alone.

I recently came across a dataset that was designed to illustrate this point exactly and I wrote a post showing why. This could be useful for communicating the importance of plotting data before diving too heavily into analysis. Do I know anyone teaching intro to stats/research methods/EDA? 

Check it out and a feedback welcome.

On the eve of the ðºð¸ election, I'm reminiscing about 2008. My advisor, Debra, invited the whole program to her apartment and she made then-soon-to-be pres Obama's favorite dish: Turkey Chilli. The atmosphere was hopeful, uncertain, but quickly turned joyous by the end of the night. 

I actually felt completely safe in NYC on that night. Random strangers were hugging and high-fiving, cheering and honking, as I walked up the Upper West Side back to my apartment. It was a simpler time.

title: Paul Apivat Hanvongse shared a link to the group: Thai R User Group.

data.post:
A friend just passed along this interest piece of tech - File-Casting - inexpensive data transfer via satellite tv.

TL;DR: Knapsack satellite File-Casting technology allows digital content to be delivered to locations otherwise disconnected due to remote geography, censorship, frequent Internet shutdowns, or high Internet cost.

https://knapsackforhope.org/

Two immediate use cases come to mind:

1. For Education companies looking to deliver digital content to rural areas without internet access. cc: @[1701022726789571:274:LearnEducation] @[100003841470862:2048:Toey Tanin]

2. For #WhatsHappenningInThailand for the day when the govt decides to shutdown ISP (I wouldn't be surprised).

When anyone comes to 'power' in ð¹ð­  *one* signature of endorsement is required. 

I'm angry at our so called 'leaders', but not under any illusion on who the puppet master is. 

#III 
#WhatsHappenningInThailand

I can't believe my kids are nearing 14th months! 

Time flies and you can never get it back (that's what I keep reminding myself). I take them on evening walks, while they're still around 10kg, but the window is closing ð They are beginning to babble, make incoherent sounds and occasionally say something that resembles language - and everyone around us is reading it into it.  Mommy thinks they're saying "mommy", grandmas and aunties are biased in the other direction. 

Personally, I think my son's first words will be a version of, "hey google, play jazz" because we say that everyday ð

Marvin is predisposed to being fearless, while my daughter Milin is more cautious. Milin started walking faster but Marvin has caught up and is now climbing ð¬ They both know how to get attention and are not shy about using their voices. 

We've set up a Montessori station, but this is an area where theory and practice diverge. We've read the book, taken some workshops, and yet in the face of a 14 month old babies - theory goes out the window. We'll take it day-by-day. If anyone else has tried to take development into their own hands, do share your experiences. 

On the work front, my data science journey continues. It started with a specific tool (R) and area of focus (people analytics), but i'm realizing this field favors the multi-lingual (hence i'm working on Python) and I don't wanna be pegged to a specific org function, like HR. 

I just finished teaching introduction to R and exploratory data visualization and will open-source my materials soon.

More details on that front here: http://getwyze.com/my-data-journey-to-yours-a-variety-of-data-flavors/

Until next time.

title: Paul Apivat Hanvongse updated his status.

data.post:
Got 2020 fatigue? 

Let's take a trip down memory lane to everyone fav icon 90's sitcom.

Friends generally got 20 - 30 million views every episode for 10 years. But for two episodes in season 2, viewership jumped to 50+ million views credit to guest starts Julia Roberts and Jean-Claude Van Damme. After the first season, the show runners must've known they had something special, so it was smart to book high profile actors to give the show a boost. 

Heat maps are aesthetically more interesting to look at when there's range restriction in the data, we see much more diversity in color for IMDB ratings (than viewership). 

When filtering for episodes with the highest ratings AND viewership, we get the seminal episodes in the show's history. These episodes, for the most part, advance the Ross/Rachel and Monica/Chandler story arc that form the backbone of the series. Take away these 7 episodes and we get a completely different show. 

Credit to the writer for imbuing the characters with a full range of emotions. While not part of the main plot, Joey and Phoebe carry their fair share of the emotional work.

#dataviz #datavisualization #tidytuesday #rstats

media.description:
I've been inspired by the activism and protest going on in the US, and wider world at large.

I wanted to take some time to think about how to channel this energy and spirit into my own work.

Here are some initial thoughts on using data, analytics and visualizations to combat oppression: 

[http://getwyze.com/data-against-oppression/](http://getwyze.com/data-against-oppression/)

For a data-driven look at police violence, brutality and racial bias, policescorecard.org has created a methodology, backed by evidence on factors that impact/deter:

- racial bias in arrests and deadly force
- unarmed civilians killed
- lethal force per arrest

https://policescorecard.org/about

Here's their dataset with Police Violence Score, Police Accountability Scores on all police departments, throughout various counties (in California; here's a nation wide look for 2017 --> https://policeviolencereport.org/). This should be of interests for all social science researchers, data analysts, data scientists and visualizers:

Hey All, 

Super thrilled to share i'm a finalists for a Data Visualization competition hosted by UPenn in partnership with Doctors Without Borders/ MÃ©decins Sans FrontiÃ¨res!

Doctors Without Borders is a medical humanitarian organization that delivers emergency aid to people affected by conflict, epidemics and natural disasters. Our task was to analyze data dating back to 1996 on their global workforce comprising 45,000 people to understand the career paths of Medical Coordinators (a top-level exec position within the organization). 

Check out the various Data Visualization and Analytics entries here: [https://wpa.wharton.upenn.edu/2020-conference-competition-winners/](https://wpa.wharton.upenn.edu/2020-conference-competition-winners/)

I just submitted a final pre-recorded video. Fingers crossed ð¤

title: Paul Apivat Hanvongse shared a link to the group: GSSE Family.

data.post:
One of the many things I didn't see coming in 2020 was that a large portion of my work would have a "medical" theme. Pre-Covid, I had applied to a Data Visualization Competition hosted at UPenn, at their flagship People Analytics Conference. 

This year, they partnered with Doctors Without Borders, a medical humanitarian organization that delivers emergency aid to people affected by conflict, epidemics and natural disasters. Our task was to analyze data dating back to 1996 on their global workforce comprising 45,000 people to understand the career paths of Medical Coordinators (a top-level exec position within the organization). 

Excited to report that I'm a finalist for the competition!!! 

I was absolutely looking forward to presenting in Philly, visiting friends in NYC and soaking in the east coast again. Alas, the virus had other plans. As with practically every other conference in every other industry, Wharton's People Analytics conference transitioned to online, remote only. We had to submit a final pre-recorded video presentation instead; I just submitted , fingers crossed!ð¤ð¤ð¤. 

For any folks interested in Data Viz / Analytics, particularly People Analytics, you can check out the various competitions here:

https://wpa.wharton.upenn.edu/2020-conference-competition-winners/

#peopleanalytics #dataviz #wpa #msf #doctorswithoutborders

Hey Dads, i'm curious if anyone has thought about home-schooling. This has crossed my mind periodically before the pandemic and even more so now. I still have *much  more thinking to do on the matter, but I'm wondering HOW are people thinking about it, if at all? I have twin 9-mos toddlers so i'm keeping an open mind at this point. Cheers !

title: Paul Apivat Hanvongse shared a post to the group: Thai R User Group.

data.post:
Hello GSSE fam,

Just wanted to share a prototype I've been working on with my medical doctor friend. It's a dashboard designed to help hospitals manage important resource during a pandemic outbreak.

Although we're on a pretty good trajectory in Thailand, one can never be too careful - and there's a possibility of a second or third wave of infections. 

So this dashboard can be used to see how various hospitals have to manage their staff, space and supplies, *efficiently* so they can service new patients. 

If anyone reading this knows of medical doctors or hospital administrators, please feel free to share as it's a work-in-progress and we're thirsty for feedback :) ð

title: Paul Apivat Hanvongse shared a post to the group: GSSE Family.

data.post:
Excited to share a prototype of a hospital dashboard i've been working with my good friend @[9434573:2048:Timothy Decha-Umphai] to create to help small-medium sized hospitals prepare *just in case* there's a second or third wave of #covid19 infections (not to mention the uncertainty around this virus).

This is a tool to help visualize some resources a hospital ð¥ needs to manage in case of a surge in patients. To minimize complexity, we focus on two primary types of data "stock" (how many supplies, staff and beds does the hospital have?) and "flow" data (how efficiently are patients being moved throughout the system?). 

As a medical doctor whose worked in hospitalist and in hospital administration, @[9434573:2048:Timothy Decha-Umphai] 's input has been invaluable. In addition, we've tried to incorporate literature on pandemic planning. It's certainly been educational for me to learn about how hospitals must manage their resources during these challenging times.

ð¢This is definitely a Work-in-Progress, so If you know any medical doctorsð©âð¬ð¨âð¬, hospital administrators, please share, we'd love to get some feedback and engagement to see if it's worth developing further. ð

This dashboard is made with R, Shiny and some Javascript. You can play with the Live App here ðð²https://paulapivat.shinyapps.io/dashboard_app/

We've written an explainer here detailing various scenarios where hospital capacity becomes strained here ðð§ http://getwyze.com/hospital-dashboard-prototype-surge-capacity-scenarios/

#dataviz #rstats #R #Shiny 

Tagging some friends who I know are doctors: @[1208938:2048:Pam Chitamitara Kennedy] @[543070871:2048:Alisa Pantanakasame Young] @[516196787:2048:Jess Ng] (pls send to your ER friends!) @[3606948:2048:Dana Kennedy]

Happy Songkran everyone! 

I'll remember this as the weirdest Songkran ever. This time is usually marked by a certain song on constant rotation (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NitOd4P7uP4) but it's oddly quiet this year. 

Who knows when things will get back to normal. I do think we're bending the curve, but we're *far* from being able to celebrate or let our guard down. 

I guess the only thing we can control is the time we spend with family and zoom with friends. So, from ours to yours, happy songkran!

media.title: Timeline Photos
media.description:
Do I know any Tour de France fans? ð¤ðµââï¸ðµââï¸

Here's a plot of how far each of the winners had to ride; from 1903 - 2019. 

On a single tour basis, Lucien Buysse had to work the hardest for his win logging 5745 kmð¥µ back in 1926. 

For context, that's cycling from Bangkok to Chiangmai and back, 4 times!

Lance Armstrong won the event 7 consecutive times (the most in history), but each of his tours were less than 4000 km...still impressive, scandal notwithstanding. 

Other names worth highlighting: Jacques Anquetil (5x winner, back in the 60's); Eddy Merckx (5x winner, early 70's); Miguel Indurain (5x winner, early 90's); Bernard Hinault (5x, late 70's) and, more recently, Chris Froome (4x, 2013 - 2017). 

#rstats #rstudio #tidyverse #ggplot2

media.title: Timeline Photos
media.description:
Just like last week, this week has seen incremental growth (good news).

However the govt lockdown has also been incrementally more strict. 

Either they are being careful (possible) or they know something we don't (also possible).

A metric that may be worth tracking now is death, it's starting to tick upwards.

data.post:
*last update: April 3rd, 2020*

This upcoming week is important, here's a score card I use to see how we're doing against #COVID19. These only reflect reported confirmed cases (i've heard anecdotally of people *not* reporting positive cases for fear of social stigma or losing face)

From March 24 - 27th, we had relatively "slow" growth in new cases (green color). 

Yesterday and Today, the growth has picked up (red) - not good. At this pace, it wouldn't surprised me if we reach 2500 by *this* Wednesday. 

Let's hope it doesn't get there.

My friend asked me what to expect in the next several weeks. Very difficult to answer given so many uncertainties. I want avoid prediction, so i'll lay out some scenarios: Good, Bad, Worse, Worst. 

Good scenario: IF we have 2500 confirmed cases on April 1st, it would be a good sign if we have 3500 by April 7th. This would suggest incremental growth.

Bad: 7000 by April 7th. More than doubled in a week's time.

Worse: 15000 by April 7th. 

Worst: 26000 by April 7th. 

Our Tests Per Confirmed Case has been dropping steadily in March suggesting that there are more new cases than new tests.

Wishlist: More aggressive testing. 

The Govt has set up check points for temperature checks. My wish is that they interrogate people with high temperature and find out who they've been in contact with in the last 7-10 days and then test *those people*. 

Will have updates tomorrow.

https://paulapivat.shinyapps.io/covidgrowth/
Happy birthday Peter! Wishing you and your family well during this crazy time!

media.title: Timeline Photos
media.description:
Need a break from covid19. Did a quick visual of brain-trauma injuries.

You'd think that Assault or Motor Vehicle related injuries would dominate. As contributors to brain trauma, they peak btwn 15-24 yrs (when we feel like we'd live forever). 

But the biggest threat is "unintentionally falling" ð ð¤ It's the largest source of brain trauma throughout our lives and increases as we age. 

On a related note, "The Fall Matrix". 

Concept is simple: if we train our bodies to get down and up off the floor, we will be using muscle and movement patterns that keep our bodies functional as we age. 

https://www.instagram.com/p/B8tvGw6nBXZ/?igshid=za025dpro4lz

#TidyTuesday dataset: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2020/2020-03-24/readme.md

Non-spectacular growth in positive cases for the third straight day; that's a positive development.

On the other hand, Testing data is now outdated because since the Government declared Emergency Decree, they have failed to report updated Testing data; that's a negative development.

media.description:
4th straight day of steady, unspectacular growth. 
Positive sign.
Otoh, no significant uptrend in testing, so possibly asymptomatic people still floating around, undetected because we're not aggressively testing.

Perhaps there could be uptick in provincial areas. Will continue to monitor, at a distance of course.

media.title: Timeline Photos
media.description:
After four days of green, we're back in the red. If this continues for several days (1.2 growth factor), we can expect 2500 cases by April 1st.

Hopefully that doesn't happen.

Testing continues to be in-line with confirmed cases. Slight increase in testing, but perhaps not enough.

à¸à¸²à¸à¸«à¸§à¸±à¸à¸§à¹à¸²à¸à¸±à¸§à¹à¸¥à¸ Testing à¸à¸­à¸à¹à¸à¸¢à¸à¸°à¹à¸à¸´à¹à¸¡à¸à¸¶à¹à¸à¸à¸²à¸¡à¸à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸ªà¸²à¸¡à¸²à¸£à¸

Growth Factor à¹à¸à¹à¸à¹à¸³à¸à¸§à¹à¸² 1.15 à¸à¸´à¸à¸à¹à¸­à¸à¸±à¸à¸ªà¸­à¸à¸§à¸±à¸à¸à¹ à¸à¸µà¹à¸à¹à¸à¸£à¸²à¸°à¹à¸à¸¥à¸§à¹à¸²à¸à¸¶à¸à¹à¸¡à¹ case à¹à¸à¸´à¹à¸¡ à¹à¸à¹à¹à¸¡à¹à¸à¸¸à¹à¸ à¸à¸°à¹à¸à¹à¹à¸«à¹à¹à¸§à¸¥à¸²à¸£à¸°à¸à¸à¸ªà¸²à¸à¸²à¸£à¸à¸ªà¸¸à¸ à¸¡à¸µà¹à¸§à¸¥à¸²à¸£à¸±à¸à¸¡à¸·à¸­

***

I want to update the dashboard, now that I have updated information.

https://paulapivat.shinyapps.io/covidgrowth/

Because Testing is emerging as a strategic tool against #covid19,
I've added Tests Per One Million People to allow cross-country comparisons. For context, S.Korea performed 6148 tests per one million people to date (United States 313, Italy 3,498 to date respectively). Data source: https://ourworldindata.org/covid-testing

For Thailand, we are currently at 169 tests per one million which *could* mean we're later in the game or have yet to ramp up our testing (the Ministry of Public Health has officially stated that our testing capacity is at 10,000 tests per day in Bangkok; provincial areas combined also at 10,000 tests per day). 

I've also added Tests Per Confirmed Cases. Some countries have tested aggressively (and proactively), so you'd expect this number to be higher, while other countries have been more reactive. For context, Italy is at approx 3.5 tests per case, US at 7 tests per case, Thailand at 14.28 tests per case, S.Korea at 35 tests per case and Taiwan at 126 tests per case. I think this number gives us a sense of how aggressive we are in testing. I'd want to see this number to go up. Data source: https://ourworldindata.org/covid-testing

Finally, Growth Factor (green) has been less than 1.15 for two consecutive days, which means there is growth, but not at an accelerated pace (for now) and our Healthcare infrastructure has some time to get ready (we want to avoid see it go to red for consecutive days).

As major parts of the city shut down and we practice social distancing, many of us fortunate to be able to work from home, are beginning to question:

- how long will we have to stay home and practice social distancing?
- how long will schools, entertainment venues shut down?
- how long until small businesses run out of cashflow?
- how long before the economy goes into a deep recession? 

No one knows for sure. 

At this point, there are more questions than answers because thereâs not enough data to reliably answer much.

What i think we *can* do is look at the data that is available to us. To that end, Iâd like to focus on numbers that donât get as much attention from the media. To be sure, there are lots of visualizations, graphics and dashboard for tracking COVID-19, so I wanted to focus on one  important aspect: itâs growth. 

I made a dashboard tracking two types of growth - the familiar day-to-day growth rate in total confirmed cases and Growth Factor. (Currently focused on Thailand, but hoping to add US/Italy/S.Korea/Singapore for comparison)

See here: https://paulapivat.shinyapps.io/covidgrowth/ 

This should give us some sense for where we are in the growth curve of this virus. If the growth factor is *consistently* between 1.15 - 1.25 or higher, it means weâll see a doubling in our total confirmed cases in about 5 days. 

Read more here: http://getwyze.com/growth-factor/

If after a period of fast growth, the number gets down to about 1.0, we might be at an inflection point where we might have peaked.

Thereâs a lot of uncertainty and these are fundamentally lagging indicators (so weâre not doing any forecasting here).

In creating this dashboard, I ran into some interesting data challenges, inconsistencies and availability. I wrote about those challenges and my temporary solution here: http://getwyze.com/tracking-covid-19-growth/

Iâll be updating this dashboard manually everyday as new numbers become available.

Be safe and happy social distancing,

title: Paul Apivat Hanvongse shared a post to the group: Thai R User Group.

data.post:
Hey all,

I'd like to share the reasoning behind my concern with #COVID19 with some data/visualizations. 

In short, the exponential growth pattern of across multiple countries is alarming. 

We've been relatively lucky to have experienced incremental growth, to date, but I fear that could change for the worse and the healthcare infrastructure in this country will be tested. 

Thai numbers are assuming accurate reporting, accurate data. 

As a university, i'm hoping we consider moving to online/remote learning as soon as possible. 

Personally speaking, I don't think this is one of those "wait and see" situations. 

At the end of the post, I share resources for individuals and organizational leaders. 

Stay safe everyone. Practice social distancing (spend time with family, at home). Wash your hands. 

http://getwyze.com/the-time-to-act-is-when-it-feels-too-early/

I'm not sensing a sufficient level of urgency around me regarding  COVID-19, so I'm sharing some data and visualizations, hoping to highlight an under-reported aspect of the coronavirus.

Those who have been following the news are aware of the numbers - confirmed cases, deaths and recovered - but these static numbers bury the lead of the story, in my view.

The important thing to grasp is the growth rate. Not incremental growth, but exponential growth.

We tend to think linearly and that's a mistake in this situation.

We feel for Italy and we think maybe it's just because they weren't prepared. But the growth rates displayed in Italy are present in many other countries. 

I think it would be foolish to think "oh that's won't happen in my country". I think we need to move to remote work/classes, practice social distancing immediately, and frankly, postpone weddings, social gatherings, conferences, meetups etc. 

Anything else is flirting with risk.

Please read on. At the end of the post I have a list of resources for individuals and organizational leaders. 

Stay safe, wash your hands and spend time with your family (at home)ð

You can learn about common (very hackable, so do NOT use these!) passwords and what you can do to make your password orders of magnitude stronger.

How has Thailand ð¹ð­ changed over the last 20 years?

One way of answering that question is to examine data on the Average Monthly Household Income for all provinces. 

This was a super fun project and i'm excited for how this one turned out. Thankful ð for data.go.th, DGA Thailand and the National Statistics Office for making publicly available these longitudinal data sets.

ðOverall trendsð: 

Largest growth in average household income from Chaiyaphum down to the Eastern seaboard, and further down south (Chumphon, Surat Thani, Phangnga and Krabi). 

Surprisingly, Chiang Mai and Chiang Rai are two among several provinces that experienced the least growth. See more details belowð

http://getwyze.com/visualizing-thailands-average-monthly-income-from-1998-2015/

For 3rd or 4th year senior students who are planning their next move after graduation, you might be interested in applying for Scholarships for graduate studies at some point.

Data.go.th has made available their Thai Government Scholarship raw data by type and country (over many years; last updated Jan 2018). 

Here's the data visualized in a Treemap so you can see which Ministry has given out the most scholarships (Ministry of Science & Technology), which scholarships favor studies in specific countries (e.g., if you wanted to study in Japan specifically, the ODOS - One District One Scholarship - is a good bet). 

Or even which scholarship has been most selective; there are two scholarships that are even more selective than the prestigious KING's scholarship (MOPH - Ministry of Public Health & MFA - Ministry of Foreign Affairs).

Full post: http://getwyze.com/a-treemap-of-government-scholarships-given-in-thailand-%f0%9f%87%b9%f0%9f%87%ad/

media.description:
"There are 82-game players, and then there are 16-game players" - @[1627882567451400:274:Draymond Green]

Well now that we're past the All-Star break, NBA fans are gearing up for the second sweetest words in the sport: Playoff Basketball. 

Casual basketball fans will know that as there's a *qualitative* difference between the regular season and the playoffs. The game slows down, teams are more strategic, defenses get tighter and the pressure is intensified. 

But can we quantitatively show this? 

In this post, we examine Giannis Antetokounmpo's impact on his team's dominance rating. Specifically, we use multiple regression to find out just how much Giannis' impact differs between the regular season and the playoffs. 

We code the NBA season as a categorical variable with two levels - regular vs playoffs - to see if Giannis is an 82-game player or a 16-game player. 

ðððð http://getwyze.com/is-giannis-a-16-game-or-an-82-game-player/

#RStats #RStudio #multipleregression #data #analytics #sportsanalytics

The more I use data visualization software like #R, the more I admire my former statistics teachers who had to draw out correlations in chalk. 

Drawing a straight forward correlation in scatter plot may seem trivial, but what about spurious correlations? 

Kinda jealous of the next gen who'll have a completely different (better!ð¥) relationship with statistics through software.

media.title: Timeline Photos
media.description:
Growing up we all wanted to me like Michael Jordan and we never cared how "efficient" he was. 

Well times have changed. The sports analytics movement started in baseball and quickly infiltrated front offices across the NBA. Now we don't just want our superstars to score 60+ points, we want to know that they did it with fewer shots (and with many 3's). 

In this post, we'll examine one of the more popular individual performance metric, the Player Efficiency Rating (created by @[292350330785985:274:John Hollinger], and whether its associated with the Team's dominance (ELO rating).

Specifically, we're looking at Giannis' PER (2018-19 season) and it's relationship to the Buck's ELO rating. 

More importantly, we're using simple linear regression.

http://getwyze.com/is-player-efficiency-rating-the-best-metric-for-individual-performance/

#rstats #rstudio #NBA #GreekFreak #regression #sportsanalytics #dataanalytics #analysis #statistics

Another post for the hoop heads ðð and data geeks ð¤ð¤ð. 

You'll often hear broadcasters say that @[8245623462:274:NBA] teams use the regular season to figure out their 7-8 man rotation and really start gelling during the playoffs. 

Well now we have at least one data point to support this. 

Building on our recent exploration of linear regression using #R #Rstudio #Rstats I created a categorical explanatory variable using the months in an NBA season to see if the @[19180542816:274:Milwaukee Bucks]  team's dominance rating (ELO, s/o @[687958677914631:274:FiveThirtyEight]) changed significantly as the 2018-19 season progressed. 

Check it out: http://getwyze.com/do-nba-teams-peak-during-the-playoffs/

#analytics #dataanalysis

An underrated skill for new #dataanalyst #datascientist is being able to take a foreign data set and generate interesting questions for further analysis. 

In this post, we'll practice using some things we've previously learned with R/Rstudio to explore, wrangle and visualize a data set from data.gov on careers/jobs in the State of Missouri ð

http://getwyze.com/exploring-and-posing-questions-of-your-data/

*side note*: If this data set exists in Thailand ð¹ð­ i'm sure school counselors could be better equipped to provide career-related guidance for young professionals.

media.title: Timeline Photos
media.description:
Been struggling to process this one all day. It's always sad when a public figure you admire passes too soon, but it's especially surreal when you grew up watching him grow up, too. 

Saw him come straight out of high school just as I was entering high school. 

From skinny kid to five-time champ. Closest thing to MJ by a long shot. Too many basketball memories to name here. 

My favorite: Game 7, Celtics, 2010. Kobe on his last fumes, broken finger, bummed knee, wasn't shooting well, but got to the line anyway. Gutted it out. 

He later retires, re-invents himself, writes children's books, produces podcasts to inspire young kids. Wins an Oscar along the way. wtf? 

What I admire most is dedication to his daughters. They were flying to a game together. 

#RIPMamba.

Photo belongs to @[60271536959:274:J.A. Adande Public Page]

media.description:
My first encounter with statistics, our undergrad prof wrote out, by handð, the equation for correlation on transparencies displayed via overhead projector (don't "ok boomer" me ð). Hated statistics. 

The graphical user interface for SPSS was certainly an improvement, but renewing that license was a pain. Our program found work arounds, but still....

Fast forward to today, we have a freeð, open source language like R and it just feels "right". This is how statistics should be taught. Computational and visualization heavy, less GUI, less hand writing equations (omg). 

Here's a post on doing some very basic linear regression in R. 

http://getwyze.com/need-to-do-light-data-work-basic-regression-in-r/

We're just getting starting and will ramp up to more advanced methods so that all  managers can have meaningful conversations with their data analyst. 

#R #Rstudio #Rstats #peopleanalytics #dataanalytics #data #analytics

TIL about HR Open Standards, an independent nonprofit promoting a standard suite of specifications to enable human resource related data exchanges.

If you work in an organization that uses Oracle, Workday, ADP or any other HRIS, making sure your vendor adopts HR Open Standards can go a long way to minimizing headaches from inconsistent (atrocious!) data.

data.post:
New Dad Starter Kit

(or what I wish I knew a week ago)

http://box5769.temp.domains/~getwyzec/new-dad-starter-kit/

So much has been said about The Future of Work, it can be disorienting trying to keep up. 

Will our jobs get automated away? 
Is my company ready for digital transformation?
Do I need to learn XYZ tech that's coming on the horizon? 

Fortunately, three concepts from organizational psychology can help bring some order to the chaos. 

Check out those concepts here: 

http://box5769.temp.domains/~getwyzec/future-of-work-performance/?fbclid=IwAR3qZE2UmJfSBptxORS3YUAbAl67mIgVCABMbLCvHiAoMrD3cUSTROwSSrk

I always thought the whole love-at-first-sight thing was BS, but I may have to change my thinking on that.

I'm falling *hard* for the twins. 

To commemorate, here's a collection of parenting advice I've received throughout the years. Shout out to the parents that took time to dish out advice - whether in person, on the phone, online or through text ð

Obviously, we're just getting started and i'm always open to crowd-sourcing wisdom from all the parents out there. 

http://box5769.temp.domains/~getwyzec/a-collection-of-parenting-advice-ive-received/

I don't remember when English became second nature for me. I do know it took years of reading, absorbing, speaking, saying the wrong thing, writing, re-writing, re-reading, keeping up with new slang, realizing years later I had been saying stuff wrong, learning new words, even 30+ years later. 

At some point, you start dreaming in the language and your inner voice becomes the language. 

I think software development is similar. 

It's hard. 

But here I am chipping at it. I guess it's like learning new phrases and trying it out in conversation. 

Here's me getting a deeper appreciation for "thinking in React" on engagement data visualization project i'm working on: 

https://www.gitpush.net/reactway/

This one's been gnawing at me for awhile. 

Long story short, @[13012333374:274:Nassim Nicholas Taleb] has taken a flame thrower ð¥ð¥ð¥ð¥ to the social sciences (including psychology). 

Help me understand why.

I'm starting with what I think is the crux of his argument - that things we think are normally distributed, actually fall under heavy-tail distributions (and implications therein).

http://box5769.temp.domains/~getwyzec/psychology-and-the-fat-tail/

I think i'm gonna start tagging some org psych folks, would love to get your two cents on this.

data.post:
My favorite band hasn't sounded this engaged in years. 

Ego, conflict, group dynamics gone wrong, I think it wore down on them and you could sense it in the live performances. 

Studio albums mask these dynamics as they're often over produced. 

You can't hide it live. The crowd knows when your solos are perfunctory. 

But they look like they're enjoying each other's company, here. I think this bodes well for the next album.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2RzQrAdzCp0     #sp #smashingpumpkins #ElLeÃ±ador

My advisor always told me to "give psychology away". 

Turns out when you wrap psychology around dry statistics, few people want it ð

Even when you incorporate some snazzy visualization, it's not enough. 

People want web apps, mobile apps and pretty soon, AR/VR apps. 

Alas, software _is_ eating the world.

For organizational psychologists who want to give psychology away, I think there's no better medium than software.

data.post:
Great #opendata event for #anticorruption hosted by ChangeFusion, some take-aways:

What interesting data would be good to fight corruption?

1. Government procurement (à¸à¸²à¸£à¸à¸±à¸à¸à¸·à¹à¸­à¸ à¸²à¸à¸£à¸±à¸)
2. Corporate Registration - LLC LTD Public Co, (à¸à¹à¸­à¸¡à¸¹à¸¥à¸à¸²à¸£à¸à¸à¸à¸°à¹à¸à¸µà¸¢à¸à¸à¸¸à¸£à¸à¸´à¸)
3. Declared Assets of Public Officials (à¸à¹à¸­à¸¡à¸¹à¸¥à¸à¸£à¸±à¸à¸¢à¹à¸ªà¸´à¸à¸à¸­à¸à¹à¸à¹à¸²à¸«à¸à¹à¸²à¸à¸µà¹à¸£à¸±à¸)
4. Corruption indicators - this seems vague (à¸à¹à¸­à¸¡à¸¹à¸¥à¸à¸²à¸£à¸à¸µà¹à¸¡à¸¹à¸¥à¸à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸à¸´à¸à¸à¸²à¸£à¸à¸­à¸£à¹à¸£à¸±à¸à¸à¸±à¹à¸)
5. Court Rulings (à¸à¸³à¸à¸±à¸à¸ªà¸´à¸à¸¨à¸²à¸¥)

Getting down to specifics for Government Procurement (à¸à¸²à¸£à¸à¸±à¸à¸à¸·à¹à¸­à¸ à¸²à¸à¸£à¸±à¸) is a good place to start. Basically *any* part of government procurement is subject to corruption: Planning, Tender, Award, Contract, Implementation. 

The key take away for open data is converting unstructured data into machine readable data - JSON and CSV data formats for the win!

My favorite case study was from Taiwanð¹ð¼ where a group of hacktivists converted 300,000+ campaign finance records to machine readable data, laying the foundation for investigate journalism to visualize the data so that ordinary citizens could see how money flowed throughout various candidate's campaign (see pictures ð) - eventually prompting the Taiwanese govt to devote more resources to making more data open. 

Thanks Sunit Shrestha for the invite, looking forward to the next session. ð

I have no doubt #opendata is good for ð¹ð­ and I admire the multi-stakeholder collaborative approach you're taking with the government.

My only concern is when our military regime of a government (I know we just had an election, but c'mon) decides some #opendata is a "threat" to national security or could fall into the hands of "bad" people and they decide to take a less-than-collaborative approach, how can we preserve the integrity of the data? How can we make data tamper-proof and censorship resistant (and beyond the reach of à¸¡44)?

As you wrap up your final exams ððand think about your summer plansð, you may be interested in this internship opportunity at - Steps with Theera, a social purpose org that provides vocational training to people with learning differences.ð¡ See attached!ð

In gradschool, we acknowledged that the MBTI had shaky empirical support, but that it served as a communication tool, giving people a language to discuss individual differences. 

But at this point, we're probably just better off using the Big-5 and telling people to stop trying to "bucket" each other into convenient categories.

In saying this, I realize no one wants to be the "extraversion, not extroverted" guy ð

Source: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/spc3.12434
Credit this user for flagging: https://twitter.com/DegenRolf/status/1090952801524613127

Following up on the previous post. Here's an attempt to work in public. The the most difficult thing was focus. I initially had 4-5 goals and yet I've preached to clients and colleagues in the past on the importance of focus.

Time to eat my own cat food. ð¸

One goal, which i'll be tracking daily/weekly. 

If you happen to be reading this, this is an open invitation to give me shit if I stray.

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/2019-in-public-6e63d83e06e6

Didn't get my final end-of-year post out in time, so i've repurposed it for the year ahead. 

S/O to @[783602990:2048:Bank Apichai Chaiwinij] for challenging me to shed 10kgs, i'm glad to be at "college" weight. Also, credit @[711951885:2048:Joey Thai] and @[551584922:2048:Tad Chanudomchok] for telling me about intermittent fasting. It worked. 

I wrote about the social aspects of goal setting in the post that anyone can apply to any goal. 

Also wrote about Lambda School and Freelancing - including an unexpected insight into the psychology of freelancing.

Finally, goals for 2019. I'm looking for a goal partner to make it publicð¢, someone who might want to put a wager on it ð°(you gotta come with your own goals) so we can really put some "teeth"ð§ââï¸ on our goals. 

Any takers? 

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/looking-back-to-look-ahead-2019-20da9a56796d

I don't think my friends who care about organizations and (free) society are excited *enough* about blockchains. 

I'm talking anyone whose ever said "power to the people", yet looked on suspiciously as only a small group seized and held onto power. Or, closer to home, you've grown tired of a select few "good moral people" deciding policy for everyone. 

Whether this sentiment happened in a small group, in an organization or society writ large. 

What if i told you that there exists spaces where you don't have to worry about power dynamics and games that are played behind the scenes? 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_IMzSCSeM68&feature=youtu.be 

How can you not be excited after listening to this?ð¤©

Everyday on twitter, my assumptions are challenged ---> Here my assumptions about economics are tested. I always thought the central story of any (healthy) economic system was about increasing returns.....a desirable outcome.......

"Any political philosophy, political economy, etc. that does not put increasing returns at its center and have a comprehensive approach to dealing with it is dead on arrival and simply misses the point of the whole exercise.

Second, beyond these abstract points, a majority of the major political problems of our time should be seen as outgrowths of a failure to deal with the problem of increasing returns in a coherent way. "

https://twitter.com/glenweyl/status/1080037811779264512

Continuing my end-of-year reflection, here are some blockchain-related things I've learned in 2018, distilled down to just five bullet points! (one of my new years resolution is to be less wordy, so I can write more). 

TL;DR version:
1. We're still so early in the blockchain game
2. Don't take out a second mortgage for experimental technology
3. Mental models are your friends
4. This is not "just" new technology
5. You CAN valuate cryptoassets, contrary to what my finance buddies tell me :)

Decembers always get me in a reflective mood. To kick off my end-of-year review, I wrote about twelve month consulting assignment that got me back in touch with my organizational psychology roots. 

Some take-aways:

1. R is an awesome open-source, powerful and free tool for analyzing large data sets. I wonder why we're still paying IBM for SPSS when free and better stuff exists. 

2. As much fun as I had getting back to the stats, it only had 20% of the impact on the client. What's more important is narrative, storytelling and communicating in a non-stats intensive way. 

Here's a retrospective, for future reference: https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/engagement-and-its-drivers-2b757a696da8

When it comes to understanding your favorite blockchain protocol, economics and game theory turn out to be invaluable tools.

Despite the ethos of decentralization, the underlying market structure of certain protocols may be more akin to "winner take all" (or at least a group of winners colluding). 

Blockchain markets may be more similar to a few large Telecom companies (think AIS, DTAC, TRUE) dominating a market than we initially thought. Left uncheck, we may see clear market dominance of certain mining pools (like the FANG stocks of blockchain mining).

When evaluating certain projects, it may be important to see if the designers are actively exploring ways to discourage (or at least check) oligopolistic tendencies. 

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/economics-games-and-proof-of-work-842d820f198c
Happy birthday my dear! May you be forever scaling new heights!ðªð§ââï¸

data.post:
Been thinking about governance lately. 

Effective governance gives us confidence that the organization we work for has not only our best interests at heart, but customers, stakeholders and wider community that we serve. 

Without good governance, you have no choice but to hope that your leader is virtuous (and competent), or a benevolent dictator. Worst case scenario, in cases where leaders lack virtue & competence, effective governance (checks and balances, a strong board) saves people from themselves. 

For public infrastructure networks (i.e., blockchains) the importance of governance is magnified 100X because there is no person to be single point of failure (ð) and, on the flip side, no person to be accountable for in case something happens to public assets (ð­). 

In this post, I borrow from the exciting multi-disciplinary field of Collective Intelligence to exam how the Ethereum network could tackle some of its governance challenges. Check it out ð¤

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/ethereum-as-collective-intelligence-77196f30156d
Congrats Orn Pornphan Banternghansa & Thanasin Tanompongphandh à¹à¸à¸µà¹à¸¢à¸§à¸ªà¹à¸à¸¥à¸¹à¸à¹à¸à¹à¸£à¸µà¸¢à¸à¸à¹à¸° :)

After my first Vipassana meditation course, it's been on my bucket list to bring my mom (who I'd hope would then convince my dad). For fourteen years I had been unsuccessful in convincing her. 

Sensing her recent interest, I quickly signed her up, drove and re-took the course with her.

For those interested, I demystify the experience here. If I can get even just one friend to go, i'll be really happy ð: https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/what-is-vipassana-604a76ededd2

It's an intense, challenging yet deeply rewarding experience, and it's open to people from all backgrounds. 

Peaceð

(Thai): http://www.thai.dhamma.org/
(International): http://www.dhamma.org/en-US/index

The men with guns want to hold onto power just a weee bit longer (no surprise). 

Some are exercising their right to protest: http://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/politics/30345994

I'm still trying to figure out which of these  "100's of new" parties are really "new": https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/new-political-parties-to-take-first-steps-to-contest-elections-in-thailand

Is my lack of faith apparent?: https://me.me/i/i-find-your-lack-of-faith-disturbing-11496077

And yet, there IS a new way: https://medium.com/@VitalikButerin/liberation-through-radical-decentralization-22fc4bedc2ac

When it comes to blockchains, the technology's not the hard part. It's a fact that anyone can fork off of an existing blockchain or create a token. What's really hard is to get people to trust that your token has value. 

And what's harder than that? 

Creating a community around your vision. 

I'm increasingly convinced that community, governance and technology are more important than market capitalization, prices or even number of transactions. 

To that end, I got a chance to see the Ethereum community up close at EDCON (Toronto); here's a write-up with lots of pictures: 

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/edcon-2018-in-pictures-f08439249be

Finally, shout out to @[516196787:2048:Jess Ng] for being such a cool host on my first, hopefully not last, trip out to Toronto!

*This* is the gold standard in online educational videos. Not the only resource, but definitely the first go-to one. This is what i'd like to see - less entertainment, more intuition building. Intuition leads to love.

There's no better way to understand current innovations in blockchain and cryptoeconomics than to trace Bitcoin's academic lineage, dating back to the 80's. 

In this installment of #100DaysOfCrypto we look at the people who influenced Satoshi, and yet even more interesting, how his status as an "academic outsider" led to the break through innovations we're witnessing today.

Cheers to not fitting in ð¥

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/when-a-giant-stand-on-the-shoulders-of-other-giants-abb134e1e83

As always, I highly encourage digging into the original article - Bitcoin's historical account - here: https://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=3136559

An interesting aspect of crypto-land is the discussions around preventing "attacks" and exploiting system vulnerabilities in "adversarial" environments. I had always wondered where these "battle" metaphors came from and why does it have to be so contentious?

Turns out this is a fundamental problem in distributed systems. 

And if we believe that culture is a pattern of assumptions that develops as a group tries to solve problems of survival (and I do), then this post also explores some cultural assumptions of cryptoeconomics - a topic i'll be diving deeper in future posts:

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/a-lot-of-us-are-jerks-adversarial-environments-94ed7069d6b4

Check out the classic Byzantine Generals Problem paper here:  https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~luca/cs174/byzantine.pdf 
#100DaysOfCrypto

For all its technological complexities, blockchain projects are very much a human endeavor. Humans who have to self-organize, coordinate, come to consensus, make decision and, resolve conflict constructively. 

I know no better group of people to help shed light on this than social-organizational psychologists. So this was particularly fun to write, to revisit the theories and empirical research we were exposed to back in grad school. 

In future posts, we'll explore potential bridges between psychology, game theory and cryptoeconomics (ooh wee! snoop dogg voice)

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/blockchain-governance-surveying-potential-contributions-from-psychology-9312a564c1b9
Happy birthday Manesh! Stay safe in the markets out there ;)

@[2000412990208935:274:Deconomy] was my first ever blockchain conference - it was pretty awesome. I tried to capture the key highlights that spoke to me in this post. 

While many people describe blockchain enthusiasm akin to religious/cult-like fervor, I found a balance of healthy skepticism and diversity of views among conference panelist. Sure, people are reeling from the drawback. But so much world-changing work is taking place in this community.

To date, blockchain technology has been dominated by computer science and complex math, but the problems waiting to be solved are not just computer science problems. There is a real opportunity for the social sciences to make a contribution. Stay tuned for more.

Shout out to the people who made my first (definitely not last) trip to S.Korea so memorable. Thanks to @[1348816420:2048:Sae Hwan Park] and @[547101910:2048:Sungmin Kim]  for taking me out and others who value their privacy too much to be mentioned :)

#Deconomy #Deconomy2018

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/deconomy-2018-retrospective-45091a4f5605

The final post in the Basics and Building Blocks portion of Crypto Canon explores "ledgers" and their role in the future blockchain economy. 

Hopefully this article can help you look past short-term price fluctuations to how the very economic fabric of society is going to change. 

When the internet took off in the late 90's, Kevin Kelly wrote a book on the net "Network Economy" (link below) that illustrated how much the internet would change business. That book for blockchain is still waiting to be written, but this article provides a glimpse.

Follow #100DaysOfCrypto and we'll continue to explore one fundamental question:

"What needs to happen, on and off the blockchain, to usher in this new âblockchain economyâ?" âï¸âï¸ð®

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/ledgers-key-to-the-blockchain-economy-d16424dc9ed9

New Rules for the New Economy: https://www.amazon.com/New-Rules-Economy-Strategies-Connected/dp/014028060X

Original article: https://medium.com/@cryptoeconomics/the-blockchain-economy-a-beginners-guide-to-institutional-cryptoeconomics-64bf2f2beec4

A continuation of Ethereum deep dive, this post looks at further applications (and potential for disruption). While i'm super excited for where Ethereum is headed, I'm mindful that its more like "pure potential" at the moment. 

A lot of infrastructure needs to be built before we get the "next"  Uber, Airbnb, Facebook, you name it. 

In any case, thinking about potential application is another way of understanding blockchain - and ultimately, people care about the applications that are built on top of blockchain; not the blockchain for its own sake. 

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/ethereum-pure-potential-31492575c574

As always, I encourage you to check out Linda Xie's original guide, as it goes beyond Ethereum to other cryptoassets (i.e., litecoin, monero, tezos and more!)

title: Paul Apivat Hanvongse wrote on Toey Tanin's timeline.

data.post:
What does renewable energy have to do with blockchain, you ask? 

Read about the @[1192675040765741:274:Power Ledger] case study I wrote up to help solidify my understanding of smart contracts to find out!

Building on the previous entry in #100DaysOfCrypto this post examine Ethereum's smart contracts functionality in the context of a live project. 

Given the regulatory uncertainty surrounding crypto (Initial Coin Offerings, in particular), some regulators have claimed that most tokens are, in fact, securities (and should be regulated as such). 

Therefore it's refreshing to see Power Ledger, an example of a project whose token has real usage beyond speculative purposes. 

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/power-ledger-2632f6ef6171

This next entry in #100DaysOfCrypto was challenging to boil down as there are a lot of details to consider (even without the complex math). 

However, I've provided a simple framework (2 min read) to help anyone digest perhaps the most exciting project in crypto: Ethereum. 

At a high level, it all boils down to smart contracts and transactions. But, the devil is in the details so I highly recommend reading the original source material. 

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/ethereum-a-few-key-ideas-c33c4e4792a7

The original article (carve out an hour, it's a long one!): 

https://medium.com/@preethikasireddy/how-does-ethereum-work-anyway-22d1df506369

Many Yin-Yang models remain rooted in dualistic either-or thinking.

This diagram moves it a step beyond, towards paradox and ambiguity...

...which is more representative.

Substitutions for "good" and "bad" can be made. 

https://i.pinimg.com/originals/96/cb/4e/96cb4ec1c92349eab08063a5a89ea886.jpg

Finally, we're moving into Ethereum, starting with a 25-minute talk by the founder himself. The technical details can get overwhelming, so I try to provide some context.

Instead of anticipating all possible use cases for blockchain applications, why not build a general purpose platform that allows other developers to dream up different projects? You know, kinda like the app store or google play? 

That's the initial thinking behind Ethereum. 

Learn more here: https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/ethereum-beyond-bitcoin-3a952c98bcb5

Check out Vitalik's 25-minute primer here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=66SaEDzlmP4&feature=youtu.be 

Also checkout Jamie Oliver's hilarious take on cryptocurrencies: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g6iDZspbRMg

#100DaysOfCrypto

In this post, we're expanding our views of blockchain beyond 'currencies'. Some see it as a new asset class and this changes the game considerably. 

How so? 

With bitcoin, we learned that the ledger stored financial transactions (i.e., does Bob really have enough money to send to Alice?). But what if the ledger could store more?

Not coincidentally, this post sets the stage nicely for Ethereum. 

Read this edition of #100DaysOfCrypto to learn more: 

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/crypto-new-asset-class-5aead68ece51

Original video source (20 minutes): 

https://a16z.com/2017/12/08/summit-crypto-alex-rampell/

#100DaysOfCrypto continues with a quick summary of posts #2 and #3 in the Crypto Canon. From these first three posts, I've come to realize that making blockchain accessible means starting off with a concrete situation that everyone's been in. 

A group of friends going out to dinner and the need to keep a running tab on who owes whom what. That's a great starting point for blockchain, but that's not all. 

A common (very valid) question asked is:

"How can you trust something that's not backed by a bank?" 

These posts explores this question, among others, and answers it. 

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/100daysofcrypto-post-2-and-3-7ee77a750056

As always, the primary sources are recommended for those who have more time:

Post #2 is a youtube clip: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bBC-nXj3Ng4&feature=youtu.be

Post #3 is a long-form article: http://www.michaelnielsen.org/ddi/how-the-bitcoin-protocol-actually-works/

[Thread 2/2]

For anyone wondering if there was a reading list or syllabus to get caught up on cryptoassets and blockchain technology, Andreessen and Horowitz has put out their "Crypto Canon". It'll get you up to speed from basic to advanced topics; the first couple entries have been really helpful.

To speed up and systematize my learning, i'm doing #100DaysOfCrypto where I digest and summarize every single entry (there's over 100 articles - a years worth of reading). I'm committing to keeping these "cliff note" summaries under 500 words, so follow along at #100DaysOfCrypto

We will cover foundations, core concepts, and special topics like governance, cryptoeconomics, privacy, scaling, consensus and even decentralized organizations (exciting stuff!).

Here's the first entry: WTF is Blockchain? 

https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/100daysofcrypto-679646824cb5

For those who want the primary sources: https://a16z.com/2018/02/10/crypto-readings-resources/

[Thread 1/2]

An ongoing project has gotten me re-connected with my org psych roots, so i'm heeding my advisor's words, to "give psychology away". 

Work is work. But there are situations where work doesn't feel like work. 

It's called engagement. 

I write about it here: 
https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/engagement-that-special-quality-53a3f90b10de

Last week, Salon.com released information about a new (in beta) project that allows their readers to opt out of seeing those annoying online ads, in exchange for 'borrowing' their CPU to mine Monero, a cryptocurrency. 

Obviously, there are privacy / security issues that need to be worked out, but this is peek into how established business models (online ads) are about to get overturned. 

I thought it was clever, but more importantly, I thought about Wikipedia. I'm a big fan of Wikipedia (aren't we all?) and although I donated in the past, I haven't been as consistent in my support. So i thought, "how might Wikipedia continue to offer their amazing, well-sourced content, WITHOUT relying on donations?" 

I ran the numbers, but I don't think Jimmy Wales agrees ð  https://medium.com/@PaulApivat/how-wikipedia-can-supplement-its-donations-based-income-4b3d0656866f

For those interested in what Salon.com is doing, see here: https://www.salon.com/about/faq-what-happens-when-i-choose-to-suppress-ads-on-salon/

I thought it'd be a smooth transition from bitcoin to ethereum, but this project is much more ambitious than I had anticipated. And yet there's still so much more to learn. 

Spend enough time in crypto and you'll realize that 'price action' and 'currency' aspects are the least interesting parts. 

While bitcoin provides a nice foundation, ethereum gets me excited about the possibilities, starting with a re-decentralizing the internet (!) 

Hopefully this provides some context for people who are curious about blockchain. I went back to the early 90's for this, when cyberspace was still a thing :)

In addition to eating less, another resolution of mine is to write more so I'll be sharing shorter pieces more frequently.

Giving myself permission to follow learning obsessions, i'll be writing a lot on crypto, but it'll be punctuating with other things i'm working on. I highly recommend you allow yourself to follow obsessions - go down rabbit holes. It's more fun.

The learning journey continues, this week, looking at securing your cryptoasset investments. Security was one of those things I hardly paid attention to until I got into this world. I can understand why this space makes some people paranoid. 

Word of caution: I get into the weeds here. While details are unavoidable, particularly when you have an asset that "no one is backing", hopefully I've explained it simply enough. As always, feedback is welcomed.

As I was catching up with friends, one of them @[783602990:2048:Bank Apichai Chaiwinij], sitting five feet away, pointed out how my expanded gut was spilling out. This happened, despite wearing a dark checkered color shirt, under dimly lit conditions. 

My friend promptly issued a challenge. 10kg. 1 year. 5000 baht. A verbal contract. If I fail to shed the kg, I pay the price. If I succeed, my friend pays. 

We've all heard of SMART goals, which has become a cliche at this point, how many are familiar with @[432874930229638:274:Jim Collins] 's catalytic mechanism? 

Coping with the revelation, I realized I had an opportunity to establish a catalytic mechanism; a goal with actual "teeth". With an added element of social pressure, now that's its posted here. 

81.5kg by December 31st, 2018. Bring it.

The best way I learn about something is to write about it. There's A LOT to learn with bitcoin or blockchain in general; probably too much information out there. 

The place to start is still Satoshi's white paper. It's a foundation for everything else.

I had considered titling this piece, "Grandma's Guide to Bitcoin"...but as the words piled on, it felt less and less grandma-friendly (but if anyone needs to explain this to their grandparents, i'm here to help). 

Nevertheless, this is a high level breakdown. If some concepts are unclear its probably because I didn't understand it well enough to explain it simply. So let me know and i'll fix that. 

Stay tuned for Ethereum.

data.post:
Some of my first year GSSE students are already making socially impactful moves! 

This particular project aims to address health disparities in villages around Siem Reap by providing sustainable bio-sand filters and nutrition education for its local communities. Furthermore, leadership training is provided for a group of local high school mentees so that they have the skills and support to continue the projects past the duration of the program, and establish a new branch of the SEALNet organization in Siem Reap of locally empowered youth.

data.post: 16 years ago, I was an exchange student at ASU's economics dept- beautiful campus, great city, awesome roommates and friends - and in 2017 i'm taking their online cert in TESOL (1 down 8 to go) to create a rigorous (and practically sound) English curriculum (very well designed MOOC btw - not just saying it as a former alum; several Coursera awards already in the bag). Learning really does never stop. The only thing missing is an actual trip back to Tempe. Hopefully soon.

Bridge International Academies (BIA), a company we've admired, has also had to manage its image as a 'for-profit' company in the education realm. 

Sometimes a tricky process.

While it has attracted many impact investors, it has also received criticism from the United Nations Committee on Rights of the Child. 

Something for us at Learn Corp to study as we think about how we position ourselves.

data.post:
My examination of the often overlooked (and underrated) Organizational factors involved in successful student-centered learning implementation in higher education (also K-12). 

English version: http://sclthailand.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/March2016-Apivat-SCL_paper-final.pdf

Thai version: http://sclthailand.org/Th/2016/03/student-centered-learning-an-organizational-imperative/

Thank you @[574103334:2048:Ptip Kanjananiyot] for working with me to get this published and expertly translated. Also check out her timely examination of the "mindset" needed to effectively engage in Quality Assurance, regardless of which system your institution is using (i.e., EdPEx, IQA, QA). 

http://sclthailand.org/2016/01/empty-quality/

For in-depth discussions of Student-Centered Learning in Thailand, by practitioners and scholars alike, check out: 

http://sclthailand.org/
Looking forward to  @[507848853:2048:Viria Vichit-Vadakan]  dropping some serious knowledge at Creative Citizen Talk 2016.

Nate Silver's reflection of his own missteps and biases are refreshing. A solid portrayal of what it means to be data-driven, humble and rigorous. Silver reminds us that just because we took statistics doesn't mean we can think statistically - this article sheds light on how to do it better. 

For anyone who needs to predict anything (i.e., sales, growth, enrollment) - this is a potent reminder of the forces working against us.
It's now or never. Make change happen for Asia with the DBS-NUS Social Venture Challenge Asia today. Submission deadline May 15th!! bit.ly/SVCAsia

title: Paul Apivat Hanvongse shared a post to the group: GLab.

data.post:
We are looking forward to this weekend's #POP-UP workshop @ FabCafe Bangkok in Ari from 1-5pm!

What will you learn?: this workshop will explore innovation leadership by diving deep into tactical methods from the THNK School of Creative Leadership and the fields of Human-Centered Design Tools and Organizational Design Frameworks. Anyone ready to innovate their creative process, organization or business model will experience transformational reframes and be able to apply the workshop experience to personal and professional projects- at the personal, team and organizational level.

Bring your real-world team challenge or learn from other participants as we walk through various tools that can be leveraged and applied to your daily work as well as the design of a team and startup/scaling organization. Join Courtney Lawrence of DSIL, Viria Vichit-Vadakan and I from G-Lab, School of Global Studies, Thammasat University
Inspiring.
Get your organization ready for breakthrough social innovation with DSIL - G-Lab, this April 23rd!!

data.post: for your reference ajarn

10 Biggest learning from a semester of teaching: 1. Classroom management may be just as important, if not more, than the actual 'content', 2. Less content may result in more learning (which kind of contradicts the next point), 3. When i wonder "is this too much for the students?" - - it's probably just right, 4. Structured team-based work is great; teams composed of friends may not be so great, 5. Students crave feedback, 6. Students want a mix of imposed structure and choice, 7. Student-centered and project-based learning works (particularly for exposure to social issues) - -but its not always obvious, 8. Lectures should be kept to 15 mins max, 9. It's important to swing from teacher-as-expert to teacher-as-facilitator/coach (and occasionally teacher-as-disciplinarian), 10. Being bilingual is critical for an 'english' program in Thailand.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=ATOu2pKm6C8

Hi everyone, first let me thank Bert-Ola Bergstrand for the invitation, I'm excited to learn more about social capital markets and the intersection of money and meaning. 

In fact, my research looks at how leaders balance 'money and meaning'. We're researching how leadership behaviors allow social entrepreneurs to balance social impact and financial performance. We currently have fantastic response rates from nonprofit leaders, but i'd LOVE to have MORE social entrepreneurs be represented in the study. 

This will help us tease out the difference, if any, between social enterprises and nonprofits. 

Please contact me if you or any social enterprise leader you know would be interested in participating in a very short (10 - 12 minutes; it goes by fast!) survey. All participants get a FREE leadership profile customized for them. 

I can be reached at aph2111@tc.columbia.edu 

Feel free to reach out if you have any questions at all. 
Thank you!!

data.post:
Hello all social enterprise leaders and social entrepreneurs! We're researching how leadership behaviors allow social entrepreneurs to balance social impact and financial performance. We currently have fantastic response rates from nonprofit leaders, but i'd LOVE to have MORE social entrepreneurs be represented in the study. 

This will help us tease out the difference, if any, between social enterprises and nonprofits. 

Please contact me if you or any social enterprise leader you know would be interested in participating in a very short (10 - 12 minutes; it goes by fast!) survey. All participants get a FREE leadership profile customized for them. 

I can be reached at aph2111@tc.columbia.edu 

Feel free to reach out if you have any questions at all. 
Thank you!!

Work and organizations are filled with competing demands and conflicting values - no where is that more true than in Social Enterprises. We're research how effective leaders best manage these tensions. We need your help!

I research how effective leaders can balance both social impact and financial performance. Currently my sample is 95% leaders from Nonprofit, but I'd LOVE to have MORE social enterprise leaders be represented. 

If you're a leader in a social enterprise, we need you! Please pass along this anonymous link to any social enterprise leader that you know. There is a FREE leadership report for all participants. 

https://tccolumbia.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_24ckKsvfpGoMz8F

If you need more information, feel free to reach out at:
aph2111@tc.columbia.edu
apivat.hanvongse@gmail.com

Thank you for participating :)
Paul

I'm conducting research on leadership in the social sector. The study looks at perceptions around leadership and organizational capabilities, social and financial impact. Please feel free to reach out if you have any questions.

Thank you for your consideration,
Paul

data.post:
It's my understanding that when you signed up for facebook, you're essentially renting cyber-land. Anything you build on that land (post) belongs to facebook (the landlord). If it's personal pictures in which you have no intention of commercializing - no harm no foul, right? [assuming that if privacy was your main concern, you wouldn't be posting in the first place]

But if you have any content you wish to benefit from in the future (i.e., commercialize, brand, sell), it's probably a good idea to get your own website (that means your facebook page shouldn't be your only online presence). Discussion welcomed.

sood love, can you translate the following and paste in our wedding group?:

Thank you everyone again for your wishes. We're trying to get a sense for how many people will join us, so if you could visit the 'event' tab and let us know if you can join us for the Reception (January 12, 2013), that would be terrific (we hope you can make it!). 

If you don't mind waking up early in the morning, we'd love to have you join us for the traditional ceremony as well. 

Also please provide us your info so we can send our physical card shortly (google document link).

Finally, for those traveling overseas, please feel free to browse the documents tab for resources. We'll be adding more resources and pictures shortly. 

Pim & Pump

title: Paul Apivat Hanvongse posted in Apiwat & Wimwipa Wedding.

data.post:
It's official, we're getting married!

We would be honored to have you join us on this auspicious occasion. After all, it's not official unless we have 'witnesses' :)

We've created this group to provide as much information as possible, especially for people traveling from overseas. We hope to use this as an information page to help you plan your trip.

In addition, we will update this group with our own pictures and stories. We hope you enjoy browsing through the site and sincerely hope to see you at the wedding.

Details
When: January 12, 2013 (Reception)
Time: 6:00 PM 
Where: Grand Hyatt Erawan, Bangkok (Map link: http://binged.it/NGsFXk)
Theme: Pink, Green, Gold

If you would like a physical card, please give us your info and we will do our best to have it delivered to you: 

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dGRnVV9SVzh2STJ0bTJPR0lJbTdmZHc6MQ

Note: You have the option of turning the notification 'off' in case you do not want notifications. However, we will be periodically posting updates to provide folks with any new information as the wedding date approaches.
